question: Femoral hernia presents:
exp: Ans. (a) Below and lateral to pubic tubercleRef: Bailey and love 26th ed, ch. 60 / 960* The femoral hernia appears below and lateral to the pubic tubercle and lies in the upper leg rather than in the lower abdomen. Inadequate exposure of this area during routine examination leads to failure to detect the hernia.* The hernia often rapidly becomes irreducible and loses any cough impulse due to the tightness of the neck. It may only be 1-2 cm in size and can easily be mistaken for a lymph node
opa: Below and lateral to pubic tubercle
opb: Above and medial to pubic tubercle
opc: Below and medial to pubic tubercle
opd: Above and lateral to pubic tubercle

question: The Neck of sac of femoral hernia lies at
exp: Ans. (a) Below and lateral to pubic tubercle.Ref: Long cases Surgery RRM* Femoral hernia impulse is felt at saphenous opening.* The question asks the landmark of saphenous opening - which is below and lateral to pubic tubercle
opa: Below and lateral to pubic tubercle

question: Hernia with highest rate of strangulation:
exp: Ans. (c) Femoral herniaRef.: Bailey & Love 26th ed. Ch. 60 / 960* High risk of strangulation is seen with femoral hernia as it has lacunar ligament (Gimbernat's) medially. This is a strong curved ligament with a sharp unyielding edge which impedes reduction of a femoral hernia.* 50% of cases present as an emergency
